The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

div.p: A Wonderfull and most Lamentable Declaration of the great hurt done, and mighty losse sustained by Fire that hapned; and mighty stormes of Winde, Thunder, Lightning, Haile, and Raine, with Inundations of Water, that fell in the Towne of Erfford and Weinmar; and in Country of Wurtenburgh, as namely in the Townes of Vagolt, Hernburg, Rotenburch, Tubingen, Issingen, Elwang, and Duncken-spiel, as also in many other places of Germany, to the great destruction of thousand of Men, Women, and Children; Houses, Cattle, Corne, Money, Houshold-stuffe, and many other things: In the Month of May, but much more in the Month of Iune last past, Anno, 1613.
With a briefe Relation of a great fire, which vpon the fourteenth of Iune, hapned in the Citty of Constantinople, and burnt fiue thousand houses.
Written to moue all good Christians to pitty and compassion, and to stirre vp their hearts to pray vnto God to conuert his Ire from vs.
Printed at Collen in High Ducth, and Translated into English.
London Printed for Thomas Archer, and are to be sold at his Shop in Popes-head Palace, 1613.

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p:
THat the great and fearefull day of the Lords terrible and last Iudgement to be giuen vpon this wicked world, is at hand, and ready to come vpon vs (good Reader) now more then sufficiently is seene and manifestly perceiued; for that daily experience, together with the fore-shewing and Prophesyings of our Lord and Sauiour Iesus Christ himselfe, and his holy Prophets doe assure vs thereof which plainely tels vs, that signes and tokens shall be seene in the firmament, and that men heere on earth should thereby and there-with be stricken into great feare, griefe, sorrow and anguish of heart, to behold the same; that the wicked and vngodly would become so obdurate and obstinate that they should vtterly reiect all warning, counsell, admonition, or instruction whatsoeuer, giuen vnto them for amendment of life, and humbling and bending of their stubborne hearts by prayer vnto the Lord, that pride, and hatred, malice, and contention, with other wickednesse and abhominations should so much therein abound,
that the Lord cannot chuse but speedily come to iudge and punish the great vn-righteousnesse of man, for proofe whereof it is needlesse to say much, when it is so manifes â€¢ ly & euidently seene daily, hourly, and continually from time to time. For was there euer more or greater wickednesse knowne and practised in the world, then is now at this day committed by all sorts of men, who daily and nightly consume their time, and the great and good gifts of God, in superflous and gluttenous eating, drinking, lust, pleasures, murthers, thefts, and many other abhominable and wicked sins and offences committed against the maiesty of God, without all remorce of conscience, or any feare of his iudgments daily shewed vpon vs. So that we cannot, but must needs confesse, that God in his righteous and iust iudgement is truly moued and incited to with-draw his mercifull and most bountifull hand from vs, and in respect of our great vnthankfulnesse towards him, and the extreame cruelties, and vnmercifulnesse by vs vsed and continually shewed vnto our Christian brethren, to strike vs with the arrowes of his fierce wrath and indignation, by his ministers of plague, pestilence, famine, warre, fire, stormes of wind, thunder, lightening, haile, raine, and inundations of water, with many other such like punishments, by vs well and meritoriously deserued at his hands. As for example. Did not God this yeare most bountifully shew forth his great goodnesse; grace & mercy throughout the whole spacious Country of Germany, by sending
them so goodly and prosperous a spring, and so seasonable a Summer, that the fruits of the earth were seene to bee so forward, faire, and in so great aboundance, as that in many hundred yeares heretofore the like was neuer seene, nor knowne? But o most mercifull God, how soone by thy mighty power hast thou ouer-whelmed the same? how soone haue they lost all their great hope? how quickly haue they beene bereaued of those goodly fruits thy great blessings? and how soone (as it were in a moment) haue they beene cast downe from the mount of felicity into the deepe valley of sorrow, woe, and extreame heauinesse? by the great stormes of wind, thunder, lightning, haile and raine, with inundations of water, and extreame fires, which many places there in Germany haue of late felt, and found, to their most great, vn-speakeable, and intollerable losse and lamentable destruction, the particulars whereof hereafter ensue.

div.head: The great and wonderfull losse sustained by Fire and Water in the Countrey of Germany, in the Months of May and Iune, in diuers places of the said Countrey; as first in the Towne of Erfford and Weinmar.
div.p: IN the Towne of Erfort, and other places in Germany, vpon the eighth day of the month of Iune last past, the weather was so vn-seasonable and stormy, that by meanes of certaine showers of raine, and extremity of haile that fell in great aboundance in that country, the water grew so high that many places thereabout were drowned, to the great and vnspeakeable hurt of the people of the same; for that the haile-stones which fell from the sky, were in many places seene and found to bee as big as pigeons and hens egges.

And specially in the towne of Weinmar, it was most extreame and terrible, whereby two milles, at least a hundred men, and many cattle, were drowned, and the water in Reinmar at that time, waxt and rose vp at least three elles higher then euer it was before: and the water called the Ilme, which tunneth by the
gate, through Naumburg, and so to Saal, rose so high that foure miles round in circuit, it ouer-whelmed and drowned all the villages & hamblets thereabouts, together with an innumerable company of men, women, and children, and great multitudes of cattle.

And about halfe a mile from Weinmar, in a small village, the water ran with so mighty a force, and such a streame, that it bare the bodies of the dead before it out of their graues in the Church-yard, and at Mulhausen and Solts drowned all their sellers, and spoiled whatsoeuer was therein: whereby at least fifty Tuns of Wine and Beere were vtterly staued & lost.

In Eiffeldt by Mulhausen at the same time, there was an hundred men, women, and children drowned, the houses by the water so vndermined, that they fell down, and were borne cleane away: and as it was found by searchching and true certificates, there was at least a thousand men, women, and children cast away and drowned within the liberties and territories of Weinmar. And for that the water continued with so great extremity to rise & rage in that manner for the space of twelue houres together, the people were forced to get into boats and in them to sit and passe along to saue themselues, singing vnto the Lord, and saying: In peace and ioy I passe along, and God our Lord and Father dwell by vs, &c.

At Magdenburg about the same time, there was at the least foure hundred houses by extremity
of water cleane cast downe and ouerwhelmed, and the storme smiting into S. Iames Church, the Organs were broken, the fonestones forcibly throwne downe, and the steeple thereof suddenly burnt.

And at Gorlitz there was so many hailestones cast into the Towne, that they lay at the least three quarters of an ell high heaped one vpon another in the same, which did great hurt and harme vnto the fruit in the Country. What such and the like prodigious things signifie and fore-shew, God knoweth.

In Leiptsig, vpon the 12 day of the moneth of Iune, the water rose so high, and increased in such aboundance, that it carried away aboue an hundred clap-bordes, the powder-mill, a stone bridge, the garden and house of pleasure, the tinne bath-stoues, couered ouer with Copper, the butchery, the fish toll-house, the rentmaisters house, the timber-house, the house wherein the prouision was kept, the Indian hen-house, the grauing-mill where the Iasper stone lay (wherein they had grauen D. Iohns Epitaph) the wodden bridge couered with tiles, the wall round about the Castle-garden, the water-worke, the pipe, and the wall about it, in the castle a round tower with a vault therein, and much timber, and the water ran in at the lop, or shot holes, (within the Castlewalkes a mans height at the least) into the towne by the Kegell tower, and the Reich-mil, the water was 16 elles high, in the corn-house
it carried away all the corne out of the nether loft, whereby it swom in the towne ditches, in the castle, and in the castle-vault, the vessels with wine and beere were ouer-throwne, so that they could by no meanes be holpen, or saued in the suddennesse of the time. In the wardrope of the castle, the Dukes apparrell and Tapestry hangings were spoiled, the Princes Orchard ouerwhelmed: in the fore roomes or part of the house, fiue and twenty horses, two and forty Cowes, two and forty Calues, forty swine, sixe fat Oxen, and many Fowles, with their stables and cages, belonging to the yong Duke, were all broken and drowned. And in the towne, in the neither mill, besides thirteene men, there was certaine quarters, or measures of corne, much houshold-stuffe, and at least a thousand gilderns in money, drowned and lost, and the millers wife, and her man lost their liues, the Reich-mill was torne in peeces, and therewith foure and forty houses and barnes, with all their houshold stuffe and prouision ouer-throwne & spoiled, and threescore and fiue men women and children drowned.

In the villages thereunto adioining, a Gentleman called Monsieur Schutz, had his house, with his houshold stuffe and cattle, and many other houses more cleane ouer-whelmed and the stone-bridge broken downe, the Gentleman and his wife, by great fortune and with great paine, and much trouble were saued.
In Erisdorp there was ten houses ouerwhelmed, and fifteene men drowned.
In Ouerweinmar the mill with ten houses was cast downe, and many men drowned.
In Deifurt nine houses, and nine men were ouerthrowne and drowned, and all the village Kromsdorf spoiled except the Parsons house, and the Gentlemans house of that towne.
In Vilerhelben four teene houses & sheepestailes were throwne to the ground, and fiue men drowned.
In Roslebn the corne house, the mill, the stoue, the worke-house, and the sheep-stalles, with at least a thousand sheepe, were all spoiled ouer-whelmed, and drowned.
In Soltelsee eight and twenty houses, and three men sunke and drowned.
In Wortstet fiue and twenty men, women, and children drowned, and ten houses onerthrowne, with the mill and the brew-house.
In Vberstadt 44 houses, and 23 men consumed and drowned.
In Drebem twenty men, and so many houses, and all Monsieur Shenkes cattle drowned.
In ouer Drebern the mill and the Brewhouse borne away.
In Soltza 20. men, and 39. houses drowned.
In the village of Soltza, the Brew-house was ouerthrowne.

In great Grumbach besides 29 houses, and many men, women, and children, with great
store of Cattle cleane borne away, there was aboue a thousand persons more drowned, for the which their was great lamentation and sorow made.

The stormy weather, and the rising of the waters was so great, that for the space of fifteene Dutch miles long, and about Erfford and Mulhausen, all the friute in the Country was spoyled and destroyed.
In Weinmar there was nineteene Maister Weisgerbies whereof there are now but three liuing.
And daily there was graues made and digged in diuers places in the Country, wherein were buried at least 10 or 12 men, women, and children, together.
So that the great hurt and misery done, and endured in these Countries of Germany is not to be told for the extremety thereof.
In the land of VVurtenberg, in Nagolt there was ten men drowned, two houses ouerwhelmed, & the corne vpon the ground spoiled.
In Hernberg, Rotenberg, Tubingen, and Islengen, the fruites, vines, and corne, were all spoiled.
About Elwang, and Dunkelspiel, there was haile-stones found that wayed two, three, and foure pound weight.
In Orterum the lightning strake into the Castle, whereby the greatest part thereof was burnt, and at least three hundred men drowned in the Riuer.

In Prage in Bohemia the stormes and tempests were so great that they did much hurt in many places throughout the country, whereby the fruits were not onely destroied, but also the water-sluces, ditches, and weares brake into the countrey, and thereby made the waters grow so high, that aboue a hundred loads of Timber, and many fats full of Corne swam vpon the water, and fishes were found and taken vpon the land.

In many places the water carried away the Sheepheards out of the field, and many hundreds of cattle drowned, and great store of horses and sheepe. So that the great losse about this time endured by the people in these Countries, by meanes thereof, amounteth vnto many hundred thousand Dollers.

p.hi: God Almighty if it bee his will and pleasure, defend, keepe and deliuer vs from the like troubles and aduersities, and turne his angry wrath and indignation from vs, which we (by reason of our great and innumerable sinnes) haue well deserued; and for the merits and passion of our Lord and Sauiour Iesus Christ his sonne, be mercifull vnto vs, and giue vs grace to liue in such a sort, that we may be alwayes ready for the Lord, whensoeuer hee calleth vs out of this world. Amen.

div.p: BY letters sent from Constantinople bearing date the 14 of Iune, it is certified to truth, that in the said Citty, thereare, by casualty of fire that hapned therein, at least fiue thousand houses burnt, and that the great losse thereby sustained, amounteth vnto more then a Million of Gold: and that the said fire was the cause of a great tumult and vprore made therein at the same time; for that the Ianizaries vnder pretence of quenching the fire robbed and ransacked the Iewes, Greekes, and Armenians houses, who thereupon making resistance against the Turkes, in the contention betweene them they slew one of the Iannisaries, for the which the next day after, they wer fined to pay ten thousand Cechinies, there-with to content and please the principall Visiere Nazut; which notwithstanding knowing a certaine Iew in Constantinople to be exceeding rich, hee caused him to be accused by false witnesses, that he was the man that slew the Iannisarie, and for the same, condemned him to die, and all his goods to be confiscated, which put the rest of the Iewes and Merchants in Constantinople in great feare and much perplexity.
